Name: heat production, air-water heat pump 10kW | heat, air-water heat pump 10kW | EN15804GD, U
Category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply
Description: Air-water heat pumps use ambient air as heat source. Here water represents the heating-circuit water. Most of the heat pumps in Switzerland are operated in a monovalent way, i.e. even at low outdoor temperatures the heat pump provides enough heat and an auxiliary system is not necessary if buildings are well insulated and a low temperature heating system is used. Air-water heat pumps are often used for retrofitting the heating system. When retrofitting heating systems in old buildings, special conditions have to be considered. Usually the heat distribution system in old buildings is operated with higher temperatures than in new buildings. For this purpose, particular retrofit heat pumps were developed. Seasonal Performance factors for retrofit heat pumps (air-water) and Swiss conditions are estimated to range between 2.5 and 2.7.;;The Seasonal Performance Factor (SPF) is an important figure which indicates the ratio between heat amount at heat pump (respectively at storage if available) and specific demand for electricity of the heat pump (incl. all common auxiliaries). The Seasonal Performance Factors are estimated, based on a comprehensive field study for heat pump installations in Switzerland. ;;Projections based on measures result on average in a SPF (SPF 2) of 3.2 for heat pumps installed in 1998 in Switzerland. (Erb et al. 2000) Heat pumps installed in 1994/95 in Switzerland showed on average a SPF of 2.6. (Erb&Hubacher 2001a) Measurements over several years have indicated that the factor hasn’t declined with age. Hence constant Seasonal Performance Factors can be assumed. The difference between values for Swiss SPF and measured COP-values of WPZ is less than 10 %. Half of the sample is at least to some extent used for heating domestic hot water. (Erb et al. 2000);;While until 1998 the analysis of Erb&Hubacher indicates rising SP factors, the COP values have risen continuously until 1995 but then have remained constant, according to measurements of the WPZ (Wärmepumpentestzentrum Winterthur-Töss). (Roth 2001) Hence a good combination of heat pump systems and building technology is essential to achieve a good SPF. (Halozan 2002);;The estimation of the Seasonal Performance Factor is based on a COP-value (Coefficient of Performance) for a B0/W35 system of 3.47 to 4.84, averaged it amounts to 3,83. These values have been measured for brine-water heat pumps with a heat capacity between 9 and 11 kW until 22nd. January 1996 (WPZ 1996). In the year 1996, heat pump manufacturer indicated COP-values between 3 and 3.5. (Multi-Energie, Grünewald 1996); responsible authorities in Zürich and Solothurn indicated values between 3.2 and 3.5 for new systems and a COP of 3 for existing systems. (Energiefachstelle Solothurn 1996, BfK 1996). Measurements of existing systems showed values between 2.2 and 3.9 (2.6 on average). (Hubacher 1996);;References:;Zogg, Martin (2002b): The Swiss Retrofit Heat Pump Programme.
